AustralianMist.Description:
Well-balanced cat of moderate foreign type
Well-sculpted facial features creating an open generous expression
Wedge-shaped head that is broad and moderately short with gently rounded contours
Wide jaw with a rounded muzzle
Short, wide nose of uniform width
Nose in line with the bottom of the chin
Recognized by: The Governing Council of the Cat Fancy  (GCCF)
AustralianMist.History:
Bred from Burmese, Abyssinian, and domestic shorthair cats
Renamed from Spotted Mist to Australian Mist when marbled coats were accepted

OjosAzules.Description:
Medium-sized cat whose eyes are blue regardless of fur color
Short, soft coat often has white patches, especially on the feet and tail tip
Head is triangular, with large eyes
OjosAzules.History: Derived by selecting for blue-eyed cats from feral populations in New Mexico in the 1980s and interbreeding them

Ragamuffin.Description: Thick coat is regarded as rabbit-like
Ragamuffin.History:
Developed from the Ragdoll by breeders working outside of the tightly controlled standards of that breed and trademark in the 1990s
Breed includes pairings with Persians, Himilayans, and other longhaired breeds to further distance it from Ragdolls

Munchkin.Description:
Small or medium-sized cat with proportionally short legs
May be shorthair or longhair, and its coat is regarded as weather-resistant
Short legs help it turn corners easily and quickly
Munchkin.History:
Breed resulting from mutation causing short legs, documented sporadically during the 20th century but not bred until the 1980s
Recognized in 1994, though controversial for claims that breeding short-legged cats may result in back, hip, and leg defects

MaineCoon.Description:
Large cat regarded as having a somewhat wild and rugged appearance
Longhaired or semi-longhaired, with a shiny, water-resistant coat
Fur is longer around its neck, on its stomach, and on its hind legs
Eyes are large and round, set at an angle
MaineCoon.History:
Breed long found in the northeastern United States, sometimes fancifully claimed to descend from cats sent by Marie Antoinette
Probably resulted from mixtures of domestic shorthaired cats with longhaired cats brought to New England by sailors
Popular as a show cat in the late 19th century, named as the State Cat of Maine in 1985

BritishLonghair.Description:
Medium to large sized cat with a dense coat of long hair that stands out
Head is broad, with large whisker pads that give it a smiling look
Coat needs extra combing as seasons change to prevent mats
Powerfully built and round, with a tendency to gain weight
BritishLonghair.History:
Known for centuries, formal breeding in the early 20th century crossed them with Persians and selected for those with long hair
Sometimes also called the Britannica, further crossbred with longhair varieties to increase numbers after World War II

ScottishFold.Description:
Rounded medium-sized cat that often has folded ears
Born with straight ears, with about 50% of kittens having their ear cartilage fold over when they are about three weeks old
Ears, when folded, bend forward and down, lending an look owl-like appearance
ScottishFold.History: Descended from barn cat found in Scotland in 1961 with unusual ears and then bred to select for kittens with the same ear trait

Chantilly.Description: Long-haired coat generally featuring saturated dark colors
Chantilly.History:
Bred from a pair of longhaired chocolate-colored cats of unknown breed in the 1960s that produced litters of the same color
Once called the Foreign-Longhair, has also been designated as the Tiffany by breeders, and can be known as the Chantilly-Tiffany

SelkirkRex.Description:
Medium-sized, curly-haired cat with the most defined curls appearing on the hindquarters, underside, and neck
May be long- or short-haired, with the longer coat having a woolly appearance
Whiskers are also curled
Solid and heavy in structure
SelkirkRex.History: Developed from single cat in litter born in Montana in 1987 with thick, curly fur, and interbred with various domestic cats

Siberian.Description:
Large, rounded cat with thick semi-long fur to protect it from cold weather
Triple-layered coat is thicker and denser in the winter
Longer hind legs and muscular hindquarters make it a good jumper
Strong and heavy in bone structure
May take up to five years to be fully mature
Siberian.History:
First mentioned in description of cat shows in England beginning in 1871, but probably existed in western Russia for centuries
Standardized in Russia during the 1980s and first brought to the United States in 1990, where it remains a rare breed

Bengal.Description:
The only domestic cat to have markings like a leopard
Generally medium-sized in proportion and well-muscled
Short coat can feature spots or marbling, and belly is usually white or light in color
Recognized by: The Governing Council of the Cat Fancy  (GCCF)
Bengal.History:
First mentioned in an 1889 description of a cat at the Regent's Park zoo in London
Hybrid offspring of the Asian Leopard Cat and domestic house cat used beginning in the 1960s to formalize the breed

Korats.Description:
Small to medium-sized cat, and the only breed to have a heart-shaped head
Fur is short and lies close to its body, sometimes giving it a sheen
Compact and heavier than it tends to appear
May take two to four years to achieve its adult eye color, and up to five years to become fully mature
Recognized by: The Governing Council of the Cat Fancy  (GCCF)
Korats.History:
Breed named for province in Thailand where it was given as a good luck gift, frequently in pairs, for centuries
Imported by England for show in the 19th century along with Siamese cats
First brought to North America in 1959 by American diplomat returning from Thailand with the cats as a gift

Donskoy.Description:
Medium-sized cat that is usually hairless and wrinkled
Born with one of four coat types (Rubber Bald, Flocked, Velour, or Brush), with all but the Brush generally ending up hairless
Capable of sweating and tanning, and may grow a coat for winter
Thumbs on its front paws bend inward, giving paws a human or monkey-like appearance
Donskoy.History:
Hairless breed developed from cat found in Rostov-on-Don by breeder Elena Kovaleva in 1987
First recognized by the World Cat Federation in 1997, genetically distinct from other hairless breeds such as the Sphynx

OrientalShorthair.Description:
Belongs to the Siamese group of breeds with a coat that can be a wide range of patterns and colors
Coat is short and lies close to its body
Long-bodied and slender proportionally
Triangular-shaped head features ears and eyes set at an angle
Recognized by: The Governing Council of the Cat Fancy  (GCCF)
OrientalShorthair.History:
Descended from Siamese cats imported to Britain in the late 19th century and mixed with local populations
Recognized for show purposes in 1977

NorwegianForest.Description:
Large cat with a thick water-resistant double-coat
Ears and toes have longer tufts of fur
Muscular and agile
May not reach maturity until five years of age
Recognized by: The Governing Council of the Cat Fancy  (GCCF)
NorwegianForest.History:
Descended from cats known in Scandinavia since 1000 A.D. and well-adapted to live in cold northern climates
Nearly extinct during the 20th century until revival by Norwegian breeders in the 1970s and designation as National Cat by King Olaf V

Sphynx.Description:
Cat that has very little hair, mostly a fine down and a few hairs on its nose and ears
Wrinkly skin and downy coat might be solid or patterned
Very large ears stand almost straight up
Known to use its toes like fingers
Body features a full-looking belly
Needs frequent bathing to remove oil, and is not considered hypoallergenic
Recognized by: The Governing Council of the Cat Fancy  (GCCF)
Sphynx.History:
First bred in Canada in the 1960s from a single cat born with a genetic mutation resulting in hairlessness
Further developed from cats born without hair interbred with cats of the various Rex breeds

Somali.Description:
Longhaired version of the Abyssinian breed
Coat is regarded as semi-longhair and shaggy, with a soft texture
Hairs feature agouti ticking, making fur look iridescent
Ear tufts, bushy fox-like tail, and brow ridge give it an undomesticated appearance
Recognized by: The Governing Council of the Cat Fancy  (GCCF)
Somali.History:
Resulted from breeding of longhaired cats born in litters of Abyssinians during the 1940s, primarily in Australia
Due to low population numbers after World War II, other cats were interbred to stabilize the breed

CaliforniaSpangled.Description:
Bred to resemble spotted wild cats, like the ocelot and leopard
A crossbreed of many strains
Long, lean, somewhat muscular body and a low slung walk, along with spots
Spots are round or blockish, but triangular, oval, or square spots acceptable
Conspicuous cheekbones and light, large whisker pads
CaliforniaSpangled.History:
Rare breed developed in the 1980s by author Paul Arnold Casey, Jr. at the behest of anthropologist Louis Leakey
Created to resemble a leopard and meant to inspire the preservation of the endangered big cats

DevonRex.Description:
Small to medium-sized cat with a wavy to curly coat
Coat is short and soft, and does not provide much insulation or shed much
Texture of its coat varies from cat to cat and within each cat's lifetime
Ears are large, low set, and prone to getting dirty
Recognized by: The Governing Council of the Cat Fancy  (GCCF)
DevonRex.History:
Descended from a kitten found near a tin mine in Devon in 1960 that was born with mutation resulting in short, curly coat
Breed kept genetically separate from similar-looking Cornish Rex through careful breeding in the 1970s

EgyptianMau.Description:
Smaller to medium sized cat, and the only naturally-spotted domesticated cat
Spots exist on its skin along with an "M" on its forehead and a stripe down its spine and tail
Outer corners of eyes are lower than its inner corners, giving it a "worried" appearance
Hind legs are longer than its forelegs, making it appear to be standing on tiptoe
Recognized by: The Governing Council of the Cat Fancy  (GCCF)
EgyptianMau.History:
Thought to descend naturally from wild African cats, the breed is seen on wall paintings in Egypt at least 3000 years old
First bred and introduced to the United States by Russian Princess Nathalie Troubetzkoy, then in exile in Italy, in the 1950s

Tonkinese.Description:
Shorthair cat that is moderate in proportions and generally has a point pattern to its coat
Coat may range from a high-contrast Pointed pattern of coloration, to Mink, to Solid
Recognized by: The Governing Council of the Cat Fancy  (GCCF)
Tonkinese.History:
Resulted from crossing Siamese and Burmese cats in the 1960s, although it may have existed as a natural mix in the 19th century
Name originally spelled "Tonkanese" and may have referred to a fictional place in the musical "South Pacific"

Balinese.Description:
Cat that has the appearance of a long-haired Siamese
Body, tail, coat, legs, and profile are all long in appearance
Fine and silky coat features darker points
Recognized by: The Governing Council of the Cat Fancy  (GCCF)
Balinese.History:
Resulted from longhaired kittens born to Siamese cats in the 1920s until they were selectively bred in the United States in the 1950s
Not native to Indonesia, named by breeders for grace and elegance supposedly resembling that of a traditional Balinese dancer

AmericanBobtail.Description:
Large cat with an undomesticated appearance and a naturally short tail
Tail is generally does not reach its hock, but is at least an inch long
Coat may be short and plush or medium-long
Well-muscled with solid bone structure
Gait, gaze, and size lend to its wild look
AmericanBobtail.History:
Claimed to result from a tabby cat bred with a bobcat, but probably came from domestic cats with a genetic predisposition for short tails
Bred from a single short-tailed tabby male named Yodie, bred with females in Iowa in the 1960s

Bombay.Description:
Burmese-type medium-sized cat that is always black, including its paw pads and nose
Short-haired with a close and shiny coat that sheds little
Eyes are large and wide-set
Muscular, making them heavier than they look
Bombay.History:
Developed in the 1960s and named for the city of Bombay due to its intended resemblance to the black leopards of India
Resulted from combining American Shorthairs with black fur with Burmese cats

Sokoke.Description:
Shorthair cat with a camouflage-pattern coat
Coat is ticked in both its ground color and pattern, and it may have outlining around its shoulders
Stands high on its legs with a tip-toe gait
Ears are large and erect
Sokoke.History:
Introduced to the west in 1978 after a Danish visitor to eastern Kenya brought some of the breed back to Denmark
Known to the Giriama people of Kenya, who called them Khadzonzos, prior to introduction to Europe
More of the cats were found in Kenya throughout the 1990s and 2000s and taken to Europe and North American for breeding

EuropeanBurmese.Description:
Solid and medium-sized cat with a short, glossy coat that usually features darker points
Kittens have pronounced points, but body darkens as it ages
Coat will be shiny if groomed with a rubber brush, petted, or polished with a chamois
Moderate shape but must not be Oriental
EuropeanBurmese.History: Variety of Burmese cat developed separately from the American Burmese, though from the same progenitor, in England in the 1950s

Peterbald.Description:
Long and thin cat that has large ears and is often hairless or mostly hairless
May totally lack a coat, have a short coat, or have something in between
Ears are large and low-set, giving them a batwing look
Paws are webbed and agile, giving them the ability to grasp things with their long toes
Requires regular bathing to remove grease and grime, as well as sun protection
Peterbald.History:
Resulted from the mixing of a Donskoy with an Oriental Shorthair in St. Petersburg in 1994
Standardized by The International Cat Association beginning in 1997

Ragdoll.Description:
One of the largest domestic breeds of cats with soft, semi-long fur
Coat may be colorpoint, mitted, or bicolor, with mitted and bicolor types having more white 
Muscular and long with no abrupt transitions or disproportionate features
Large size means it may not reach full maturity until four years old
Ragdoll.History:
Developed from longhaired breeds in California in the 1960s and named for their tendency to go limp when picked up
Population expanded when a group of breeders broke from control of the original breeder in the 1970s and developed the standard

JapaneseBobtail.Description:
Bobbed tail is kinked and curved, giving it the appearance of a rabbit's tail or pompom
Coat may be long or short, but its silky texture and minimal undercoat makes it easy to keep groomed
Head features angular lines and eyes have a prominent slant
Hind legs form a Z, making it a strong jumper
JapaneseBobtail.History:
Descended from cats used to catch rodents in Japan in the 17th century, described in 1701 in "Kaempfer's Japan"
First imported to North America in 1968 and bred until being recognized for show in 1976

HavanaBrown.Description:
Medium-sized cat with a smooth solid color coat and a blunt-rounded muzzle
Whiskers match coat color
Head features a prominent stop, square chin, and a pinch at the muzzle
Ears tilt forward
Recognized by: The Governing Council of the Cat Fancy  (GCCF)
HavanaBrown.History:
Developed in England in the 19th and 20th centuries by selecting for brown-colored Siamese cats and mixing them with other breeds
Recognized as the Chestnut Foreign Shorthair in 1958 before name change to Havana in 1970

BritishShorthair.Description:
Medium-to-large size with a broad body and smiling appearance
Short coat is plush and dense, requiring extra grooming in the fall and spring to prevent mats
Heavy and muscular, with a tendency to eat too much and become overweight
Head is round, with chubby cheeks and a short nose
Recognized by: The Governing Council of the Cat Fancy  (GCCF)
BritishShorthair.History:
Descended from cats brought to the British Isles by the ancient Romans and interbred with local cats
Crossbred with thick-coated Persian cats, standardized in the 19th century and shown in 1871 at the Crystal Palace cat show
Breed numbers declined by the 1940s but was revived by fanciers following World War II

Persian.Description:
Medium or large in size cat with a long coat and a round face
Coat may be long enough to reach the floor, and can be silky or cottony in texture, depending on the color
Head is round, with a short muzzle
Short and square in shape, with a muscular build
Recognized by: The Governing Council of the Cat Fancy  (GCCF)
Persian.History:
Old breed first documented in the western world by an Italian traveler who brought them back from Persia around 1620
Original cats from Persia and Afghanistan interbred with various longhaired varieties for centuries
First shown at the Crystal Palace cat show in London in 1871 and imported to North America beginning around 1900

Ocicat.Description:
Large cat with a spotted coat and the appearance of a wild cat
Short, glossy fur is ticked, with bands of color on each hair
Coat may be polished with a chamois after brushing
Muscular and strong
Ocicat.History:
Developed accidentally by a breeder in Michigan in the 1960s mixing Abyssinian and Siamese cats and finding spotted offspring
Further developed in the 1980s with the introduction of American Shorthaired cats to the breeding pool

GermanRex.Description:
Medium-sized cat with a short, curly coat
Eyes are proportionally large
GermanRex.History: Curly-coated breed resulting from genetic mutations, bred from a single female stray found near Berlin in 1951

Snowshoe.Description:
Shorthair cat with pointed coloration and white paws
Born white, acquiring darker colors on its head, ears, tail, and legs as it ages
Legs are proportionally long
Recognized by: The Governing Council of the Cat Fancy  (GCCF)
Snowshoe.History:
American breed developed in Philadelphia in the 1960s when an accidental mutation resulted in Siamese kittens born with white feet
First litter of white-footed Siamese cats crossbred with American Shorthairs, considered a rare breed

Cymric.Description:
Round cat that most often is born tailless, like a Manx, with a coat that is medium-long
Coat is thick and features fluffy breeches and a ruff
Hind legs are longer than its front legs, raising its rump and giving it a hopping gait
May have a short or full-length tail
Cymric.History:
Breed descended from Manx cats and possibly further developed in Canada in the 1960s, despite the name associating it with Wales
Resulted from mutations of Manx cats born with long hair

TurkishAngora.Description:
Semi-longhaired cat with a soft and seasonal coat
Fur in winter is longer than in summer, especially on its neck, hind legs, and tail
Fine-boned and long in its legs and body
Coat needs to be groomed infrequently, as it is not prone to matting
TurkishAngora.History:
Descended from longhaired cats known in Turkey for centuries until they were interbred with Persians almost to the point of extinction
Bred by the Turkish government in a program at the Ankara Zoo in the early 20th century to preserve the breed
Limited export allowed in the 1960s, leading to a breeding pair being sent to the United States

Chartreux.Description:
Large cat with a wide body and short, thin limbs
Coat is always blue in color, and is double, with a wooly and water-resistant top coat
Rounded head and long muzzle gives them a smiling appearance
Eyes are large and contrast in color with its coat
Chartreux.History:
French breed named for legendary association with 13th century crusaders bringing them back to Carthusian monasteries
Mentioned in French literature by the 16th century by the naturalist Georges-Louis Leclerc, Comte de Buffon in the 18th century
Reduced in numbers during the World Wars, but mixed with British Shorthairs and Persians to preserve the breed

Toyger.Description:
Medium-sized cat with the appearance of a small tiger
Shorthair coat features branched vertical stripes at random intervals, a lighter underside, and circular facial markings
High shoulders gives it a rolling gait
Body is long and deep, and face is shaped like a long heart
Toyger.History:
Created beginning in 1980 by a breeder trying to clarify markings on striped tabbies, and adding Bengal cats for a bigger body
Breeders in the United States also imported stray cats with specific markings from India to interbreed

Laperm.Description:
Cat with a curly, mohair-textured coat
Fur's curls are tightest at its ears, neck, and belly, and it may be longhaired or shorthaired
Sheds little, and is not prone to matting
Medium in proportions
Recognized by: The Governing Council of the Cat Fancy  (GCCF)
Laperm.History:
Originated from a single kitten with a mutation for soft, tightly curled fur, born to a litter on a cherry farm in Oregon in 1982
Named for the curly coat while also referencing the Chinook Native American tradition of adopting French words for things

Manx.Description:
Round cat that is often born tailless
Fur is short and dense, with harder guard hairs that give a glossy look
Tail can be entirely missing to normal length
Long hind legs give it a hopping gait
Recognized by: The Governing Council of the Cat Fancy  (GCCF)
Manx.History:
Originated before 1750 on the Isle of Man and also known as the Stubbin, for their distinctive lack of a tail
Shown beginning in the late 19th century and became the subject of many folktales about its origins and appearance

Savannah.Description:
Large but lightweight cat that resembles the African Serval in appearance
Coat features distinct markings, mostly spots
Ears are large and upright, and are set on the top of its head
Neck, legs, and body are long
Savannah.History:
Resulted from the crossbreeding of a wild African cat, the Serval, with a Siamese cat in 1986
Standardized and accepted by The International Cat Association in 2001

KurilianBobtail.Description:
Medium- to large-sized cat with a short, kinked tail
Tail may be two to ten vertebrae long, and kinked many times to be shaped like a whisk, spiral, or snag
Coat can be short or semi-long, and is silky in texture and not prone to matting
Head and body are large and wide
KurilianBobtail.History:
Originated on the North Atlantic islands of Russia and Japan, including the Kurils and Sakhalin, known as early as 1800
Brought to central Russia during the 20th century where the breed became popular as a pet and for catching mice

TurkishVan.Description:
Large cat whose waterproof coat allows it to swim and play in the water
Semi-longhair coat is mostly white, with patches of color on its head and tail
Coat is longer in the winter, including between its paw pads
Eyes are often non-matching in color
Holds its plumed tail upright when running
May not reach full maturity until it is three to five years old
Recognized by: The Governing Council of the Cat Fancy  (GCCF)
TurkishVan.History:
Breed native to the mountainous region of eastern Turkey, though further developed in England after the 1950s
Rare breed certified for show by The International Cat Association in 1979

Nebelung.Description:
Medium-sized cat with a longhair coat that features silver tips
Dense coat requires frequent grooming to prevent matting
Long-bodied and well-muscled
Eyes are wide-set and ears are proportionally large
Nebelung.History:
Developed from pair of cats resembling the Russian Blue but with longer coats, bred together in the United States in the 1980s
Name comes from the German for "fog" and the "Nibelungenlied," a medieval saga featuring the namesakes of the first pair, Brunhilde and Siegfried

Burmese.Description:
Solid and medium-sized cat with a short, glossy coat that usually features darker points
Kittens have pronounced points, but body darkens as it ages
Coat will be shiny if groomed with a rubber brush, petted, or polished with a chamois
Sturdy build
Recognized by: The Governing Council of the Cat Fancy  (GCCF)
Burmese.History:
First known from poems from modern-day Thailand written prior to the 18th century, taken to Burma by 18th century invaders
Modern Burmese cats descended from a female named Wong Mau imported and bred by Dr. Joseph C. Thompson in San Francisco in 1930

YorkChocolate.Description: Longhaired cat with a soft coat that stands away from its body
YorkChocolate.History: Named for New York where it was first bred in 1983 as a show cat, primarily by selecting for brown kittens from longhaired cats

Abyssinian.Description:
Medium-sized and muscular cat with a ticked coat and the general appearance of a mountain lion
Coat appears iridescent due to its agouti ticking, with bands of color on each hair
Also exists in a Somali variety, which has a  longer coat and furnishings on its ears and tail
Large eyes are surrounded by dark "eyeliner" and then another ring of lighter color
Recognized by: The Governing Council of the Cat Fancy  (GCCF)
Abyssinian.History:
Developed in Egypt in the mid-19th century, despite the reference in the breed's name to Ethiopia, and ay descend from cats depicted in ancient Egyptian art
Further developed in Great Britain after being brought by soldiers
Known in the United States since first being shown there in 1909, and grew in popularity during the 1930s

Himalayan.Description:
Medium to large size with the appearance of a Persian breed, but has blue eyes and point coloration
Coat is long and requires frequent grooming to keep the undercoat from matting
Broad head features a wide snub nose, large wide set eyes, and small low set ears
Heavy in bone structure, and wide across the body
Recognized by: The Governing Council of the Cat Fancy  (GCCF)
Himalayan.History:
Bred beginning in 1931 by mixing Persian cats with Siamese cats for their coloration and blue eyes
Gained recognition as the Colorpoint Longhair during the 1950s

AmericanWirehair.Description:
Medium-sized and proportioned cat which has a wiry coat
Coat is springy and may be spiked or curly, with the hairs being hooked, crimped, or bent
May require bathing, as it may have sensitive or oily skin
Reaches full maturity at around age three or four
AmericanWirehair.History:
Resulted from random mutation found in one kitten in a litter of American Shorthairs born in New York in 1966
Bred from a single male in the 1960s and 70s, and recognized by the Cat Fanciers' Association in 1978, but remains a rare breed

Tiffanie.Description:
Longhaired type of the Burmilla breed
Coat has a silver background with a tip of color on each hair
Fur is fine and medium long, shorter at its shoulders and longer at its neck and tail
Needs grooming infrequently, as it does not have an undercoat and fur does not tangle
Recognized by: The Governing Council of the Cat Fancy  (GCCF)
Tiffanie.History: New breed developed in Australia in the late 1990s by breeding Burmillas and selecting for those with longer hair than normal

Birman.Description:
Medium-sized cat whose coat features dark points and white paws
All four paws have white gloves, and the back paws feature white laces up the back of its legs
Hair is semi-long and silky to the touch, and requires some grooming to keep it from matting
Stockily-built, with muscular legs
Recognized by: The Governing Council of the Cat Fancy  (GCCF)
Birman.History:
First known in Nice, France in the 1920s, though often claimed to originate as companions of priests in Burmese temples
Nearly extinct in Europe following World War II but restored through interbreeding with other longhaired breeds through the 1950s
Imported to the United States and recognized there as a breed in the 1960s

SiameseTraditional.Description:
Shorthair cat with moderate proportions and angles
Fur has a colorpoint pattern, with dark extremities and a light body
Forehead is wide, flat, and rounded on the sides, along with its cheeks and muzzle
SiameseTraditional.History:
Known in Thailand for centuries as the Wichien-Maat, imported by the British to Europe in the 19th century
Likely first brought to the United States as a gift from the American Consul in Bangkok to President Rutherford B. Hayes
Bred for show in Great Britain from the beginning of the 20th century

ChineseLiHuaMao.Description:
Relatively large cat whose coat is a brown mackerel tabby pattern, with clear markings and ticked hairs
Strong and sturdy in proportion
May take three years to reach full maturity
Eyes are large and a rounded almond shape
ChineseLiHuaMao.History:
Breed that may have resulted from self-domestication of the Chinese mountain cat alongside human populations
Known from descriptions in early Chinese folklore, but only debuted as an experimental breed class in Beijing in 2003

OrientalLonghair.Description:
Member of the Siamese group of breeds with a semi-long coat
Long and thin in its body, head, feet, and tail
Head is wedge-shaped, straight in profile, and features ears and eyes set at an angle
Fine-boned but muscular
OrientalLonghair.History:
First bred in England beginning in the 1950s by mixing Siamese with various domestic cats including British Shorthairs
Known until 2002 as the British Angora

ExoticShorthair.Description:
Large square cat that is a short-haired variety of the Persian cat
Coat is short and dense, and easier than the Persian to keep groomed
Head is broad with large round eyes, low set ears, and a shortened face
Heavy in bone structure, with short legs and body
Recognized by: The Governing Council of the Cat Fancy  (GCCF)
ExoticShorthair.History:
Breed resulting from crossing American Shorthairs with Persians in the 1950s and 60s
Breed was mixed with the Russian Blue and the Burmese before being formalized in 1987 and only mixed with Persians

Javanese.Description: Oriental-type cat with a long, silky-textured coat
Javanese.History: Bred as a longhaired version of the Oriental, named for the Indonesian island by American breeders around 1950

ColorpointShorthair.Description:
Siamese cat with pointed markings
Coat may be any color other than seal, chocolate, blue, and lilac, as these are the traditional Siamese colors
ColorpointShorthair.History: Closely related to the Siamese, with which it was bred with American Shorthairs to achieve different colorations in the 1940s

Minskin.Description:
Short-legged cat that is mostly hairless, excepting fur points
Body may be sparsely furred, and face, ears, nose, legs, tail have soft short fur
Legs are short and body is somewhat stocky
Minskin.History: Resulted from crossing Munchkin cats with short legs and Sphynx cats in 1998 to create a breed with hair only at the extremities

PixieBob.Description:
Medium to large in size and heavy cat that has a bobbed tail and are often polydactyl
Coat may be short or medium in length, and is thick, double-layered, and woolly in texture
Generally spotted, with small spots and heavily ticked hairs
Tail is usually between two inches long and to the hock, and is flexible but kinked or knotted
Often has more than five toes on one or both of its front paws and/or more than four toes on one or both of its back paws
PixieBob.History:
Bred from short-tailed cat found in Washington in 1985 and a domestic cat, then further crossed with similar looking feral cats
Accepted and standardized for show purposes beginning in 1994

Chausie.Description:
Cat that is medium or large in size and resembles the Jungle Cat in appearance
Full muzzle and prominent chin as well as large erect ears give it a wild appearance
Only domestic cat to have a black grizzled tabby coat
Tall and long, with a deep chest and a slim body
Chausie.History: Breed created in the 1960s to domesticate and reduce the size of jungle cats by hybridizing them with Abyssinians

Highlander.Description:
Large muscular cat whose ears curl at the top third
Coat may be short or long
Muzzle has a boxy appearance, with a deep chin and wide nose
Eyes are large, oval, and set wide apart
Tail is naturally short and expressive, and may not always be straight
Highlander.History: Developed beginning in 2004 and intended to resemble larger, wild cats such as the lynx

EuropeanShorthair.Description:
Cat of a medium to large size that has a short, dense, and glossy coat that may be any color or pattern
Head is proportionally large and rounded in shape
Body is muscular and broad through the chest
EuropeanShorthair.History:
Closely associated with British Shorthairs until 1982 when the Federation Internationale Feline registered it as a distinct breed
Separated from British Shorthairs by Scandinavian breeders who kept Persians out of their mixes

Recognized by: The Governing Council of the Cat Fancy  (GCCF)
Burmilla.History: Breed first created in the United Kingdom in 1981 when a Chinchilla Persian cat and a Burmese were accidentally allowed to mate

AmericanShorthair.Description:
Considered medium in size, proportions, musculature, and boning
Coat is short, hard, smooth, dense, and requires almost no grooming
Adapts to a wide range of living situations
Matures fully at around three or four years of age
AmericanShorthair.History:
Developed from cats used to catch mice on ships carrying European settlers to North America
Selective breeding in the United States in the early 20th century emphasized the desirable characteristics of the breed

CornishRex.Description:
Wavy to curly coat that consists of only an undercoat with no guard hairs
Curly eyebrows and whiskers
Long-legged, with an arched back and tuck-up
Regarded as a good choice for people who suffer from allergies and do not need much grooming
Recognized by: The Governing Council of the Cat Fancy  (GCCF)
CornishRex.History:
Resulted from litter of kittens born in Cornwall in 1950 with genetic mutation that produced a curly coat of fine fur
Male of the original litter bred with mother and offspring, breed was then gradually mixed with Siamese and other breeds through the 1960s

Serengeti.Description:
Medium sized cat with proportionally large ears and black-spotted short fur
Ears are set on top of its head and are round at the ends
Sits in an erect position
Serengeti.History:
New breed intended to look like wild cats, including the serval, but without interbreeding with wild cats
First developed in California in the 1990s by breeding Bengal and Oriental cats together

Singapura.Description:
One of the smallest breeds of domestic cat
Coat is lighter on the underside, and features a darker M on the forehead as well as bars on the legs
Eyes and ears are proportionally large
May not reach full adult size until two years old
Recognized by: The Governing Council of the Cat Fancy  (GCCF)
Singapura.History:
Developed from three cats brought to the United States from Singapore in the mid-1970s
After original breeding, more cats resembling the first group were brought from Singapore and added to the breeding pool

SiameseModern.Description:
Long and angular shorthair cat
Coat is fine in texture, tight, and glossy
Point-shaded, with darker mask, ears, legs, and tail
Eye are almond-shaped and set in a slant, with the outer corners higher than their inner corners
Recognized by: The Governing Council of the Cat Fancy  (GCCF)
SiameseModern.History: Closely related to the Siamese Traditional but differentiated by selection for a narrower body and triangular head

RussianBlue.Description:
Medium-sized cat whose short coat is always silver-tipped blue
Fur is dense and stands away from its body, appearing to shimmer in movement
Ears are proportionally large and flared
Appears to smile
Fine boned, with long legs
Recognized by: The Governing Council of the Cat Fancy  (GCCF)
RussianBlue.History:
Breed brought from the area of Arkhangel in northwestern Russia to England in the 1860s, and shown at the Crystal Palace in 1875
Reduced in numbers after World War II when the breed was revived by mixing with Siamese or British Shorthairs with blue coloration

AmericanCurl.Description:
Medium-sized cat with ears that curl out and back into a rosebud position
Born with straight ears which start to curl back when they are a few days old and finish at about 16 weeks
Eyes are large and round in shape
Coat may be long or short, and is silky in texture with minimal shedding
AmericanCurl.History:
Originated from a stray kitten with a random mutation resulting in curled ears found and bred in California in 1981
Developed in the 1980s and fully recognized by The International Cat Association in 1987
